Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: Collaborative Research: Contour-Assisted Visual Inference: Systems, Algorithms, and Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Occlusion contour (OC) is well known to play important roles in many computer vision tasks. Unlike regular photographs, an OC image removes the effects of illumination, texture, and appearance while preserving important depth edges and silhouette. This project develops a comprehensive framework for acquiring, processing, and utilizing OCs in visual inference tasks. On the sensor front, the research team develops a new Occlusion Contour Camera or OC-Cam. The new OC-Cam extends the multi-flash camera by coupling an array of controllable infrared (IR) LEDs and a visible-IR camera pair. On the algorithm and application fronts, the research team systematically develops OC-assisted visual inference algorithms. For recognition, the acquired OCs are used as a feature filter to improve category-level object recognition. For tracking, the PIs apply OCs to enhance target representation by filtering out the background and texture edges. Furthermore, the research team investigates the previously under-explored problems of OC-assisted image summarization and privacy protection.

This project can cast deep impact on broad areas of computer vision, artificial intelligence, criminal justices, and robotics, both in research and education. Due to the importance of OCs in human vision, the results can produce a testbed for the study of visual psychology. Furthermore, the OC-Cam is expected to serve as conceptual inspiration for constructing the next-generation surveillance systems. Finally, the captured OC datasets and relevant tools are made available to other researchers, to provide a platform for validating new OC-based computer vision algorithms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Occlusion contour (OC) is well known to play a useful roles in many computer vision tasks. Unlike regular photographs, an OC image removes the effects of illumination, texture, and appearance while preserving important depth edges and silhouette. Despite its usefulness, two fundamental issues remain. First, most previous approaches require manually extracting OCs from the imagery data. Second, there lacks a systematic approach to incorporate OCs in visual inference algorithms such as tracking, recognition, and saliency detection.


In this project, we have developed a comprehensive framework for acquiring, processing, and utilizing OCs in visual inference tasks. On the sensor front, we have developed a new Occlusion Contour Camera or OC-Cam. This new sensor builds upon the PI's multi-flash camera that takes successive photos of a scene with flash lights at different locations. The shadow variations across the flash lights are then used to extract OCs. We have developed a mobile version of the multi-flash camera that triggers the flashes by the mobile device's own flash and have demonstrate the effectiveness of the system.

On the algorithm and application front, we have systematically developed OC-assisted visual inference algorithms. At the core of our approach is a novel and effective scheme for measuring the similarity between OCs. The new measure has served as elementary building blocks for various algorithms. For recognition, we have developed solutions with novel discriminative representations by using OCs as a feature filter to improve category-level object recognition. For tracking, we have applied OCs to enhance target representation by filtering out the background and integrated the results with the L1-trackers. We have further investigated using OCs as saliency measures for improving saliency detection and content-based image retargeting. 

This project has led to a large number of publications at premiere computer vision conferences such as CVPR, IEEE, and ECCV. The fund has been extensively used to support graduate students and post-docs. We believe the results will have deep impact on broad areas of computer vision, artificialintelligence, and criminal justices, and disaster controls, both inresearch and education. Due to the importance of OCs in human vision, our study generates potential contribution and testbed to the study of visual saliency. The research results have been integrated into the instructions of courses such as computer graphics, computational photography and computer algorithms.
